title: Will the European Parliament vote before 1 April 2017 to establish a European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS)?
preds: With Article 50 being triggered and Germany now being the EU's largest economy, I doubt that anything will get passed without their support anytime soon.

EU regulatory roundup 2016 and 2017 Imeson (2017) Jan 20, states that: Banking Union Banking Union applies to all countries in the euro area, with non-euro countries able to join if they wish. It has three main elements: (para. 23).
•	The Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM), with the European Central Bank (ECB) the lead supervisor. It came into being in November 2014, with banks gradually adjusting to the new regime throughout 2015.
•	The Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation (SRMR), whose purpose is to ensure an orderly sale or winding up (“resolution”) for failing banks, with minimal costs to taxpayers and the real economy. The SRM was brought into effect through a Regulation on 1 January 2016.
•	The European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS), which will protect up to €100,000 per depositor per bank if a bank fails. It has not yet been implement (para. 23-26). Imeson, M. (2017). EU regulatory roundup 2016 and 2017. Wolters Kluwer. Retrieved from
http://www.wolterskluwerfs.com/article/eu-regulatory-round-up-2016-and-2017.aspx

Europe is falling apart, not coming together with a common fiscal and regulatory framework. What could change the forecast is a new crisis.

“The European Council underlines the need to complete the Banking Union in terms of reducing and sharing risks in the financial sector, in the appropriate order,” read the conclusions of the regular summit of EU leaders.The appropriate order is understood by the Germans as meaning that, first, banks in countries like Italy or Portugal should become fitter, for instance by getting rid of bad loans. And only later, richer member states would agree to put their money in common funds to shield deposits and lenders from future failures. An initial version of the summit conclusions, circulated among EU diplomats and seen by Reuters, said new risk reduction measures were already approved and paved the way for more risk sharing.In November, the European Commission proposed new capital rules for the bloc’s lenders, introducing in the EU stricter standards agreed at international level meant to make banks safer.But Germany and the Netherlands said the new measures were not enough to reduce risks and urged stricter requirements. They opposed the initial draft conclusions and successfully pushed for amending the text, two EU officials told Reuters. Officials said the fragility of the banking sector in Italy, where the country’s third largest lender Monte dei Paschi di Siena has been entangled for months in attempts to close a big capital shortfall, has made Berlin even less keen to agree on plans to share risks.
https://www.euractiv.com/section/euro-finance/news/germany-blocks-small-progress-on-banking-union-at-eu-summit/
Extremely low probability event. With several elections scheduled in H1CY17, political will to negotiate is likely to be missing in Italy, France and Germany.

http://www.europarl.europa.eu/oeil/popups/ficheprocedure.do?lang=&reference=2015/0270(COD) Work in progress The Work in Progress shows the legislative procedures currently in progress in each committee. Each entry indicates the type of procedure, the name of the rapporteur and whether the committee has been called upon as the committee responsible or to give its opinion. Entries also contain a link to the Legislative Observatory, which shows the entire detail of the procedure, including any relevant documents. Once a procedure has finished at the committee stage, it will be voted on in plenary and will then be deemed to be completed.
http://www.europarl.europa.eu/committees/en/econ/work-in-progress.html? Even the very first stage has yet to be completed, so being voted on by April 2017 is unlikely.

The possibility of Britain exiting the single market just makes the case for CMU stronger and more urgent.

COMMENT:  The banking union in the European Union is the transfer of responsibility for banking policy from the national to the EU level in several countries of the European Union, initiated in 2012 as a response to the Eurozone crisis. The motivation for banking union was the fragility of numerous banks in the Eurozone, and the identification of vicious circle between credit conditions for these banks and the sovereign credit of their respective home countries. In several countries, private debts arising from a property bubble were transferred to sovereign debt as a result of banking system bailouts and government responses to slowing economies post-bubble. Banking union was formulated as a policy response to this challenge. There is a need for it. Whether it is within the time frame is another question.

Vice-President Valdis Dombrovskis at the Eurofi Financial Forum 2016, Bratislava "Work on the European Deposit Insurance Scheme (EDIS) is now in the hands of the co-legislators. The Commission has made a clear legislative proposal to gradually mutualise national deposit guarantee schemes. To pool contributions and build the fire power we need.   Now, I hope we can build on the on the Council Roadmap to get this agreed."
http://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_SPEECH-16-2993_en.htm

Due to the prevalent economic climate in the EU, there is little   Or no appetite for new economic initiatives.

It is worth noting what this question is not asking; it not asking if an EDIS would be a good idea; it is not asking if the EU will establish an EDIS. I think an EDIS is a good idea, but there is zero chance of an agreement to set one up before 1 Apr 2017. It seems pretty clear that voters who assume that the deposits in banks in their country are safe don't want to subsidise what they see as high risk bank deposits in other countries that might not be able bail out deposits. (Banks is some "safe" countries might be a higher risk than the voters think, but the voters are right to believe that the "safe" countries do have national balance sheets that could bail out depositors). 
Another complication is that an EDIS could be for only banks in the Euro Zone or for all banks in the EU. It would seem very unlikely that post Brexit vote an EDIS that included the UK would be proposed. 
The actual question concerns not the EU Commission or  EU Council of Ministers, but only the EU Parliament. The EU Parliament has already published the list of matters than it intends to work on over the remainder of this year, and there is no mention (that I can see) of an EDIS.  We know that French elections will be coming up early in 2017, followed a few months later by German elections. I can't think why France, Germany, the UK,  Ireland, Netherlands, any Nordic country or most of the Eastern European countries would be keen to vote for an EDIS in the next 8 months. I could see Greek, Italian and maybe Portuguese MEPs wanting an EDIS, but not a majority of MEPs.  But its always possible that the European Parliament could vote for an EDIS knowing it will not be implemented.
This is one where it is difficult to separate what one thinks will actually happen from one is pretty sure would be a good policy.  Stay tuned.

Extraordinarily improbable by April 1, 2017, given that Germany needs to be fully satisfied that sufficient risk reduction has been achieved before seriously discussing this third pillar of financial stability.  If the EU is really going to work, it should happen someday.  But probably not until the supervision pillar is a lot tougher.
If it will help for reducing  the Europe economic problems, it will be good for Europe union

I think this more likely than some of my colleagues: Jonathan Hill's replacement at the Commission, the Latvian Commissioner formerly responsible for the Euro, is a committed integrationist. With the UK, whose European Parliament members would have opposed this, now effectively a bystander, its prospects in Parliament are likely improved. German opposition would matter more in the European Council, but that would kill the plan at a later stage.
Timeframe appears to be too short to work out technical details, overcome political gridlock, and go through the process required to put it to a vote.

"Germany prioritises finalising the implementation of the existing rules, in particular the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive (BRRD). Although the deadline was 31 December 2014, only half of the member states had fully adopted it by early August. The BRRD aims to reduce the cost of bank resolution by making the financial institutions pay the lion’s share before using taxpayer money." Looks like France and Belgium have still to implement.
http://www2.isda.org/isda-brrd-implementation-monitor/ EU leaders even decided to scrap a succinct reference to the completion of the Banking Union, which was initially included in the summit conclusions. Diverging views between Germany and France, combined with Berlin’s hesitation to complete the Banking Union have killed attempts progress on what was initially billed a key priority for this political term. However, the EU deposit guarantee scheme has triggered Germany’s protest, even more after Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker announced in his state of the union speech that the legislative proposal will come by the end of the year, earlier than expected. “To now start a discussion on further mutualisation of bank risks through a common deposit insurance or an European deposit reinsurance scheme is unacceptable,” the German delegation said in paper sent to the capitals ahead of the Ecofin Council.
